com.camerontec.catalys.mis.ums.ldap

Class SampleLDAPUserDetailsProvider

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.camerontec.catalys.mis.ums.ldap.SampleLDAPUserDetailsProvider
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ICustomUserDetailsProvider, IUserDetailsProvider

    public class SampleLDAPUserDetailsProvider
extends Object
implements ICustomUserDetailsProvider
    Sample custom UMS provider that uses LDAP to retrieve user details from a Directory Server.
    This class is provided only for the purpose of illustrating how a custom UMS provider may be implemented. It is not a fully functional UMS provider implementation, because such an implementation would heavily depend on the schema of the LDAP server in use. More precisely:
    • The only implemented methods are getAllUsers(), getUser(String) and userExists(String).
    • For the above methods, only a subset of the information pertaining to a user is extracted:
      • A user's password is always null. This is because LDAP servers typically do not store passwords as attributes but instead require that a bind authentication be performed to log users in. This functionality is outside the scope of the UMS but is supported by the Dashboard via a custom LDAP-based JAAS authenticator.
      • Permissions are hard-coded to the entire set of available permissions in the Dashboard. Permissions may be exposed in a single attribute that we would need to tokenize, via a multi-valued attribute or any other mechanism supported by the directory server.
      • All users are enabled.
      • We do not retrieve user locales.
      • We do not retrieve group information. This may be exposed in a variety of ways by the directory server: single or multi-valued attributes, separate entries representing groups, etc.
    • All other methods that are expected to read from the remote directory return null or empty results.
    • All other methods that are expected to write to the remote directory throw an UnsupportedOperationException.
    Using this implementation in conjunction with an LDAP authenticator, it is possible to log in to the Dashboard using LDAP credentials and to visualize all users in the Dashboard's admin tab.
    This implementation also supports a mapping for the Dashboard's special "admin" user, which is mapped to a user called "administrator" in the directory server.
